titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the National Biscuit Company Photograph, n.d.
titlestmt.subtitle: National Biscuit Company Photograph Ms2017-018

titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections Ms2017-018

defitem.label: Processed by: Kira A. Dietz, Archivist,

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.abstract: The collection consists of a single black and white photograph of a group of National Biscuit Company salesman and delivery drivers posed outside of a factory. Most of the men are carrying cracker display units and the trucks in the background are advertising Uneeda Biscuits. The photograph is not dated.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from National Biscuit Company Photograph must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: National Biscuit Company Photograph, Ms2017-018, Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The National Biscuit Company Photograph was purchased by Special Collections in February 2016.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the National Biscuit Company Photograph was completed in June 2017.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Founded in 1898, the National Biscuit Company was the product of a merger among the American Biscuit and Manufacturing Company, the New York Biscuit Company, and the United States Baking Company. The new conglomerate consisted of one hundred-fourteen bakeries across the United States and was headquartered in New York City.

Though the name "Nabisco" was first used as the name for a specific product introduced in 1901 (a sugar wafer), and was used within the company at least as early as the 1930s (likely sooner), the corporate name was not shortened to Nabisco, Inc. until 1971.

In 1981, Nabisco merged with Standard Brands, Inc., which later became part of R. J. Reynolds. It has since become part of several more mergers and separations. It is currently a subsidiary of Mondelēz International.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of a single black and white photograph of a group of National Biscuit Company salesman and delivery drivers posed outside of a factory. Most of the men are carrying cracker display units and the trucks in the background are advertising Uneeda Biscuits. The photograph is not dated.

list.item: Culinary Pamphlet Collection (Ms2011-002), especially Box 2, Folder 42. Finding aid available online.
National Biscuit Company Salesman's Collection (Ms2017-017). Finding aid available online.
National Biscuit Company Package Catalog (Ms2017-019). Finding aid available online.
